data.title: Philosophyball
data.text:
Stoicism is an ancient Hellenistic philosophy originating around 300 BC in Athens by Zeno of Citium, posits that virtue alone leads to eudaimonia, or a flourishing life. Its core tenets include practicing wisdom, courage, moderation, and justice daily, and living harmoniously with nature. Alongside Aristotle's ethics, Stoicism forms a cornerstone of virtue ethics, asserting that virtue—rather than external goods like health or wealth—is the sole good for humanity. Stoics like Seneca and Epictetus emphasized emotional resilience and maintaining a will aligned with nature. Despite declining after Christianity's rise in the 4th century AD, Stoicism has experienced resurgences, including during the Renaissance and in modern times.

History[edit | edit source]

Early Stoicism [edit | edit source]

The founder of stoicism, Zeno of Citium, developed his theory while living in Athens. Zeno and the other early Stoics who came after him like Epictetus and Chrysippus of Soli developed the basic framework of Stoicism, such as the universal friendship of all who are virtuous, the division of philosophy into physics, ethics, and metaphysics, and the stoical conception of the Logos.

Stoicism in Rome [edit | edit source]

Stoicism, with it's emphases on courage in the face of strife, appealed to those living in the turbulent world of Ancient. It quickly became one of the most popular philosophies amongst the elite, with Stoic concepts like appeal to natural law becoming an ordinary part of civic life.

Modern Stoicism [edit | edit source]

The ideas of Stoicism have seen a revival in recent years, mostly as a method of self help, divorced from much of the original framework. However, in modern analytic philosophy, there are some who have taken interest in a somewhat more holistic view of Stoicism.

Philosophical Beliefs[edit | edit source]

Logic[edit | edit source]

Diodorus Cronus, a teacher of Zeno, is credited with pioneering propositional logic, a method centered on statements rather than terms, contrasting sharply with Aristotle's term-based logic. Chrysippus later refined this into Stoic logic, known for its deductive system called Stoic Syllogistic, which rivaled Aristotle's own Syllogistic.

Stoic logic experienced a resurgence in the 20th century due to significant advancements in propositional logic. According to Susanne Bobzien, Chrysippus authored over 300 books covering a wide array of logical topics such as speech act theory, sentence analysis, singular and plural expressions, types of predicates, indexicals, existential propositions, logical connectors, negations, disjunctions, conditionals, logical consequence, valid argument forms, deduction theory, propositional logic, modal logic, tense logic, epistemic logic, suppositional logic, imperative logic, ambiguity, and logical paradoxes.

Categories[edit | edit source]

The Stoics believed that everything that exists is material, although not everything is. They acknowledged four immaterial entities: time, place, void, and what can be said. These were considered to exist but not as concrete substances like universals. They accepted the concept that specific qualities in objects, such as being hot or red, are because part of a universal quality has entered the object. This idea extended to all attributes, unlike Aristotle who applied it selectively.

The Stoics categorized things into four groups:

Substance: Primary matter, the formless substance (ousia) from which things are made.

Quality: How matter is organized to create individual objects; in Stoic physics, it involves a physical element (pneuma: air or breath) that informs the matter.

Somehow disposed: Specific characteristics not inherently within the object, like size, shape, action, or posture.

Somehow disposed in relation to something: Characteristics related to other phenomena, such as an object's position in time and space relative to others.

The Stoics also emphasized personal agency and control over actions, thoughts, and reactions. The opening of the Enchiridion states: "Some things are within our power, while others are not. Within our power are our faculties of judgment, motivation, desire, and aversion—everything that is our own doing." To illustrate these categories, Jacques Brunschwig offers a straightforward example: "I am a physical entity, a substance; I am a man, defined by common and unique qualities; I am in a certain posture or state; I am a father, a fellow citizen, situated in relation to others."

Epistemology[edit | edit source]

The Stoics believed that knowledge is acquired through reason. They held that truth can be distinguished from falsehood, although only approximately in practice. According to them, our senses continually receive sensations: vibrations transmitted from objects through the senses to the mind, where they leave an impression in the imagination (phantasiai), known as a phantasma.

The mind possesses the ability to judge (συγκατάθεσις, synkatathesis)—to accept or reject—an impression, allowing it to discern whether a representation of reality is true or false. Some impressions can be immediately accepted, while others only gain hesitant approval, categorized as belief or opinion (doxa). Clear understanding and conviction (katalepsis) are achieved only through reason. The Stoics believed that certain and true knowledge (episteme), attainable by the wise Stoic sage, is confirmed through peer review and collective human judgment.

Physics[edit | edit source]

According to Stoic philosophy, the Universe is a rational and material entity known as the logos. It is divided into two components: the passive and the active. The passive part is matter, described as inert and awaiting activation by external forces. The active part is an intelligent aether or primordial fire, which interacts with passive matter.

In Stoic thought, the Universe itself is considered divine, encompassing its own soul and guiding principle. It operates through mind and reason, governing the natural order of all things. This includes the elements in flux—water, earth, and air—as well as celestial bodies like the sun, moon, and stars. Everything within the Universe, including human and animal souls, is subject to the laws of Fate, which govern the natural processes and movements. Individual souls, according to Stoicism, originate from this primordial Fire and are subject to transmutation. They return to their source, the seminal reason ("logos spermatikos") of the Universe, and maintain a connection with the universal Reason that underlies both humanity and the cosmos.

Stoic theology can be described as a fatalistic and naturalistic form of pantheism. Unlike Abrahamic religions that personify God as a distinct creator, Stoicism identifies God with the entirety of the Universe. In Stoic cosmology, time and space are cyclical and infinite. The Universe undergoes cycles of creation and destruction (ekpyrōsis), with each phase being preceded and succeeded by an infinite number of Universes. This cyclical view emphasizes the eternal self-creation and self-destruction of the cosmos, a concept akin to the Hindu notion of existence.

Ethics[edit | edit source]

Stoic ethics teaches that true good resides in the soul itself, found through wisdom and self-control. The goal is to rid oneself of passions. For Stoics, reason involves using logic and understanding the natural order guided by the logos, or universal reason, present in everything. The term "pathos" in Greek encompasses various strong emotions like anger, fear, and excessive joy. Stoics viewed passions as disruptive and misguided mental forces arising from faulty reasoning. According to Chrysippus, passions stem from mistaken value judgments where something indifferent is wrongly perceived as good or bad. This erroneous judgment leads to emotions like delight from misjudging present goods or anxiety due to unfounded fears about the future.

The Stoic ideal is to accurately assess things based on their true value, recognizing that passions are not inherent but arise from flawed reasoning. Freedom from passions leads to a self-contained happiness where there is no fear, as irrationality alone is seen as harmful, and no cause for anger, since others cannot truly harm a person who is rational and self-controlled.

Passions[edit | edit source]

The Stoics categorized passions into four main types: distress, pleasure, fear, and lust. According to Chrysippus, these were defined as follows:

Distress: Irrational contraction or the belief that something bad is currently present, leading to depression.

Fear: Irrational aversion or avoidance of anticipated danger.

Lust: Irrational desire or pursuit of something believed to be good but actually harmful.

Delight: Irrational elation or the belief that something good is currently present, leading to joy.

These passions can be further categorized based on whether they concern present or future events:

Present

Good: Delight

Evil: Distress

Future

Good: Lust

Evil: Fear

Each passion category encompasses various specific emotions:

Distress: Envy, Rivalry, Jealousy, Compassion, Anxiety, Mourning, Sadness, Troubling, Grief, Lamenting, Depression, Vexation, Despondency.

Fear: Sluggishness, Shame, Fright, Timidity, Consternation, Pusillanimity, Bewilderment, Faintheartedness.

Lust: Anger, Rage, Hatred, Enmity, Wrath, Greed, Longing.

Delight: Malice, Rapture, Ostentation.

In Stoic philosophy, the wise person (sophos) achieves apatheia, freedom from these passions. Instead, they experience eupatheia, which are clear-headed and rational emotions. These include joy (chara), wish (boulesis), and caution (eulabeia). Each of these good-feelings can also be subdivided:

Joy: Enjoyment, Cheerfulness, Good spirits.

Wish: Good intent, Goodwill, Welcoming, Cherishing, Love.

Caution: Moral shame, Reverence.

Suicide[edit | edit source]

The Stoics believed that suicide could be acceptable for a wise person facing circumstances that might prevent them from living virtuously, like severe pain or disease. However, in most cases, suicide would be seen as failing to fulfill one's social duties. For instance, according to Plutarch, Cato the Younger believed that living under tyranny would compromise his consistency as a Stoic and limit his freedom to make honorable moral choices.

Love and Sexuality[edit | edit source]

Early Stoics, like Zeno, held different views on sexuality and relationships compared to later Stoics. Zeno proposed a republic governed by love rather than laws, where marriage would be abolished and spouses would be shared. He supported both heterosexual and homosexual relationships, seeing them as opportunities for moral education and virtue development. However, he did not condemn marriage itself, viewing it as a natural institution. Zeno emphasized love over mere desire, arguing that the purpose of sexual relations should be virtue and friendship. Later Stoics, such as Epictetus, similarly considered both homosexual and heterosexual attractions equivalent in their potential for promoting virtue. They criticized desires that could lead one to act against reason but did not outright oppose sexual relationships.

In contrast, contemporaneous Stoics increasingly equated sexuality with passion. While they did not oppose sexual relationships in principle, they believed in limiting them to maintain self-control. For instance, Musonius Rufus argued that the only natural sexual activity was for procreation, advocating for a companionate marriage between a man and a woman. He viewed relationships pursued purely for pleasure or affection as unnatural.

Political Beliefs[edit | edit source]

Virtuous Government [edit | edit source]

According to Stoics it was possible for any type of government to be a just and good government as long as it followed the 4 stoic virtues (especially the virtue of Justice). Marcus Aurelius defined 2 types of good governments - Democracy where power belongs to the people and Monarchy where one individual serves their people, ruling over them in accordance with people's will.

Doubled Citizenship [edit | edit source]

Emperor Marcus Aurelius believed every human being has two citizenships and two sets of responsibilities that come with them. First is the citizenship of your homeland and responsibilities you have to your countryman and the second citizenship is to the Cosmopolis - The community of the world, that comes with responsibilities to the world and humankind as a whole.

Personality[edit | edit source]

Stoicism is generally a very peaceful ball, preferring debates over violent fights. He loves philosophy and often finds himself contemplating the nature of the universe and morality. He tries to live by his 4 virtues believing them to be what shall lead him to becoming a better person.

How to Draw[edit | edit source]

Draw a Dark Red (#89000d) ball

Draw a Golden (#fdd105) symbol of a flame on it

Encircle the Flame with a Golden Circle and add 4 smaller circles on the larger circle dividing it into 4 equal parts

Add Eyes

(Optional) Add a Laurel Crown on top of the Ball

Done

Relationships[edit | edit source]

Friends[edit | edit source]

Aristotelianism - Probably the school of thought that most influenced Stoicism.

Virtue Ethics - Truly there is nothing greater then virtue.

Moral Universalism - And anyone can be virtuous!

Asceticism - A stoic must strive to be virtuous in mind.

Eudaimonism - A stoic must also strive to be virtuous in deeds.

Frenemies[edit | edit source]

Christianity - Many of them like my writings but I don't care for their zeal.

Paganism - Similar to the previous ones. Virtue comes from logos, friend.

Aristocracy - I mean sure as long as the aristocrats are virtuous, it should be alright.

Monarchism - As long as the ruler is a virtuous person they can rule wisely in the name of the people.

Senatorialism - The Senate is a place where both the most virtuous and wicked of Rome congregate.

Cynicism - Look, I understand you're trying to be virtuous and live in accordance with nature, and I know Zeno started out as a Cynic, but for the love of the divine, can you please stop masturbating in public?

Redbeardianism - You like me, but your avarice confuse me.

Enemies[edit | edit source]

Totalitarianism - A wise ruler does not rule by fear alone!

Plutocracy - You only care about your wealth not justice!

Oligarchy - I literally can't tell you apart!

Ochlocracy - When democracy forgets virtue, nothing but blind mob remains.

Nihilism - While not yet hedonistic he opens the path for vice & labels virtue as meaningless.

Hedonism - One of the reasons bad emperors arise so that he would torture the world for his enjoyment.

Machiavellianism - They disregard virtue and only care about personal gain. But Machiavelli said Marcus Aurelius was a good emperor.

Quotes[edit | edit source]

Athenian Stoicism/Early Stoicism[edit | edit source]

“We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen more than we say.” - Zeno

“Man conquers the world by conquering himself.” - Zeno

“A bad feeling is a commotion of the mind repugnant to reason, and against nature.” - Zeno

“If you lay violent hands on me, you’ll have my body, but my mind will remain with Stilpo.” - Zeno

Roman Stoicism[edit | edit source]

“Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together, but do so with all your heart.” - Marcus Aurelius

“Think of the life you have lived until now as over and, as a dead man, see what’s left as a bonus and live it according to Nature. Love the hand that fate deals you and play it as your own, for what could be more fitting?” - Marcus Aurelius
